channel.title: Articles by Daniel Gonzales on Tech Terminologies
channel.description: Recent content in Articles by Daniel Gonzales on Tech Terminologies

item.title: What is Bandwidth Allocation?
item.description: Bandwidth allocation refers to the process of dividing and managing the available bandwidth of a network among its users or devices.

item.title: What is an IP Address?
item.description: An IP address is a unique numerical label assigned to each device connected to a computer network that uses the Internet Protocol for communication.

item.title: What is a Private WAN (Wide Area Network)?
item.description: A private WAN (Wide Area Network) is a communications network that is owned and operated by a single organization.

item.title: What is a VLAN (Virtual Local Area Network)?
item.description: A Virtual Local Area Network (VLAN) is a logical group of devices on a physical network that behave as if they are on a separate network.

item.title: What is a Binary File?
item.description: A binary file is a type of computer file that contains data in a binary format, which is a series of bits that represent machine-readable instructions and data.

item.title: What is Shift Left Testing?
item.description: Shift left testing is a software testing approach that involves shifting testing activities to earlier stages of the software development process.

item.title: What is a Trojan (Trojan Horse)?
item.description: A Trojan horse, or Trojan, is a type of malicious software that is designed to deceive users into believing it is legitimate while actually performing undesirable or harmful actions on their systems.

item.title: What is a Quad-Core?
item.description: A quad-core processor is a type of central processing unit (CPU) that has four independent processing cores on the same die, or physical chip.

item.title: What is a Webcam?
item.description: A webcam is a digital video camera that is connected to a computer or computer network, allowing it to transmit real-time video footage to a remote location.

item.title: What is an Animated GIF?
item.description: An animated GIF (short for Graphics Interchange Format) is a type of digital image file that allows for the creation of simple animations.

item.title: What is a Bitmap?
item.description: A bitmap is a type of digital image file that represents a grid of pixels as a collection of bits.

item.title: What is a Raw File Format (Raw Image Format)?
item.description: A raw image format is a file format that stores unprocessed data from a digital camera’s image sensor.

item.title: What is a Graphical Installer?
item.description: A “graphical installer” is a software installation program that presents users with a graphical user interface (GUI) rather than a command-line interface (CLI).

item.title: What is a Compiler?
item.description: A compiler is a computer program that translates code written in a programming language into machine code that can be executed by a computer.

item.title: What is a Permalink?
item.description: A permalink, short for “permanent link,” is a URL (Uniform Resource Locator) that is intended to remain unchanged for the lifetime of the content to which it refers.

item.title: What is E-commerce?
item.description: The term “e-commerce,” which stands for “electronic commerce,” describes the process of buying and selling products and services through the internet.

item.title: What is 5G?
item.description: 5G is the fifth generation of mobile network technology that is designed to provide faster and more reliable internet connectivity to devices such as smartphones, tablets, and laptops.

item.title: What is CDN (Content Delivery Network)?
item.description: A Content Delivery Network (CDN) is a globally distributed network of servers that work together to deliver content to users as efficiently as possible.

item.title: What is Wireless Charging?
item.description: Wireless charging is a technology that allows devices to be charged without the need for a physical connection to a charger or power outlet.

item.title: What is Edge Computing?
item.description: Edge computing is a distributed computing paradigm that brings computation and data storage closer to the edge of the network, where data is generated and consumed.

item.title: What is a Product Key?
item.description: A product key, also known as a license key or activation key, is a unique alphanumeric code that is required to install and activate a software application.

item.title: What is CGI (Common Gateway Interface)?
item.description: CGI (Common Gateway Interface) is a standard protocol for executing scripts or programs over the Internet.

item.title: What is BSB (Backside Bus)?
item.description: The backside bus (BSB) is a bus that connects the CPU to the level 2 (L2) cache on a computer.

item.title: What is Apple Silicon?
item.description: Apple Silicon is a line of computer processors developed and manufactured by Apple Inc.

item.title: What is a Network Adapter?
item.description: A network adapter, also known as a network interface card (NIC), is a hardware component that allows a computer to connect to a network.

item.title: What is Active-Matrix Organic Light-Emitting Diode (AMOLED)
item.description: Active-matrix organic light-emitting diode (AMOLED) is a type of OLED display technology in which the pixels are driven by an active matrix circuit, which consists of thin-film transistors (TFTs) and capacitors.

item.title: What is a 3D Printer?
item.description: A 3D printer is a machine that creates physical objects from digital designs.

item.title: What is APL (A Programming Language)?
item.description: APL (A Programming Language) is a programming language that was developed in the 1960s by Kenneth E.
